segments.text: Could you give your full name?
My name is Robert G. Tow.
And this is June 1, Tuesday, 1993, at the University of Texas, Austin Astronomy Department.
Where were you born, Bob?
I was born in Jackson, Michigan, on May 1, 1929.
When did you first get—how did you first get interested in astronomy?
Oh, there were two or three events.

I remember one event when I was extremely young, and I have not yet been able to identify this event, but there was a very heavy meteor shower, which we saw when we were driving in our old Willie's Night from Brooklyn to Jackson, Michigan, late one night.
The meteors were coming down very heavily, almost straight down like a rainstorm.
In later years, I thought that perhaps this was the Jacobinid shower of 1933, but I've more recently understood that that was not seen in the United States.
A more recent event was the Jacobinid meteor shower of 1946, but by that time I was already almost through high school and far along on my interest in astronomy.
I had a very good view of that particular meteor shower.
Where'd you go to undergraduate school?
University of Illinois.
First at Navy Pier and then down in Champaign.
And what was your major?
Physics.
Physics.
And when did you get your degree?
Fifty-two.
Okay.
Then you went to graduate school, and where did you go?
Well, I didn't go immediately to graduate school.
I went to work for a year at the
with the Signal Corps, U.S. Army, and then they drafted me, and I worked for two more years for them.
And I went to the University of Illinois Graduate School for two years.
Got my master's degree.
At that time, there was no Ph.D. program at Illinois, and Stan Wyatt and... Ivan King?
No, no, McVitie.
McVitie.
George McVitie advised.
me to try Michigan.
Therefore, I enrolled at the University of Michigan in 1957.
As I recall, when you were still at Illinois, you already had a well-developed ability to build instruments because you built a plate-holding camera for the 12-inch refractor with

Well, I discovered that there was a lathe and a rudimentary shop in the basement of that old observatory on the University of Illinois campus, and certainly George McVitie didn't discourage me from trying some things.
In fact, there was one summer when I didn't have much to do, and he was going to be away from campus, and he suggested, well, why don't you give that
old 30-inch mirror sitting under the stairs to test.
I said, okay, I'll do it.
And I went ahead and built a very elaborate testing apparatus down in the shop there.
Then I found some space in the basement of the physics building to set it up and do these tests.
Called a truck to come over and pick up the mirror.
It was still in its crate.
I had not opened the crate yet.
They came and they backed the truck up to the steps of the observatory whereupon the steps collapsed down into the basement.
They finally did get the mirror into the truck and over to the physics building and we opened up the crate and the mirror had a deep radial crack from its
center out about two-thirds of the way to the edge, and therefore was essentially useless.
I did spend a few days just going through some rudimentary tests.
However, it was something like a 30-inch F1.5 or F2.
Was this the one where the guy in Indiana was going to use it to photograph the souls of the recently departed?
That's exactly the one.
Or is it now?
Well, I don't know.
As far as I know, it's still in the basement of the physics building.
What did you do for your—when did you get your Ph.D. at Michigan?
And what was your dissertation on?
It was on spectrophotometry of the nucleus—or the nuclear region of M-31.
And who was your advisor?
Bill Lilly.
Oh, okay.
Okay, so let's see, that was 60?
Okay, then it's time to look for a job.
Well, okay, yeah.
In 61, Gerard de Vaucouleur and Frank Edmonds here at the University of Texas called and invited me to spend a few months here in Austin helping to design a couple of astronomical instruments.
I guess they heard about me at a meeting someplace and decided to give me a try.
Well, at that stage in my graduate studies, both I and my wife were pretty exhausted and we decided this is a good chance to take a break.
So we spent four months here in Austin, designed a spectrum scanner
to be used on the 82-inch telescope.
And then on the 1st of January, 70 degrees here in Austin, we left for back home.
By the time we got there, it was zero degrees in Michigan.
And we moved back into our old environment for a few months, finishing up graduate work in Michigan.
While I was here in Austin, Frank Edmonds
and Gerard Vogeler invited me to join the faculty here at Texas.
And when did you do that?
I did that in the fall of 62.
Okay, so how many faculty were there then?
The fourth one or something like that?
Something like that, yes.
There's a photograph I think up here.
Okay, Bob Tull is now unfolding a photograph of the five horsemen, and from left to right, they are Harlan Smith, a very young-looking juror of the Book of Lore, Bob Tull.
Who's the other guy?
This is Frank Edmonds, of course, and this is...
The fifth man is Terry Deeming, who was here for a few years.
He was primarily a mathematician, did a lot of theoretical work,
And he eventually moved to a mathematical firm in Houston called Digicon.
He passed away about two years ago.
The faculty's a lot bigger now.
Is it any better, you think?
Oh, I believe so.
There's a wide variety of interests in the faculty at the present moment, including the theoretical and the experimental.
And observational astronomy is very strong here at the University of Texas.
Well, when you got here, what did you do?
What have they been having you do for the last 30 years?
Well, my first seven years here, I was on the teaching faculty.

About the third or fourth year, the University of Texas became very active in planning and building a new hundred and seven inch telescope, which Ron Shorn of course was instrumental in some of that early planning.
Harlan Smith at one stage asked me to join the
the project, which required me to drop one of my summer research grants.
And from that point on, I was heavily involved in the construction of the 107-inch telescope, which involved the design of the Coudet spectrograph, the testing of the 107-inch mirror at the
manufacturer Davidson Optronics in West Covina, California.
The tests were completed in 1968.
The telescope came together that year and the first observation was done on March 9th, the night of March 8th of 1969.
was my observation, which was a high-resolution spectrum of Arcturus.
And what did you do after the 107-inch?
After the 107-inch, I became a member of the research staff at McDonald Observatory as what was called a research scientist.
This was a relatively new type of position for the University of Texas.

Eventually, the research staff of the McDonald Observatory increased as much as did the faculty, and at the present moment we have roughly equal numbers of faculty and research scientists, like 20 to 22 of each.
During the ensuing years, I have been involved for part of the time in observational astronomy, but I found long ago that my interest in instrumentation would keep me from ever reducing this data.
And I decided eventually that it was a waste of telescope time for me to occupy a telescope for an observing run.
and then just sit on the data.
So I gradually moved over entirely into instrumentation.
There's a fellow just like you at the Center for Astrophysics, John Geary.
Do you know him?
Oh, yes.
I know John Geary.
I was drinking wine with him last morning.
And you're two guys I had in mind, because whether you're planetary astronomers or scholar astronomers or what, we all use your stuff.
And I don't think you guys get enough credit.
Do you think you get enough credit?
No, I don't.
Well, I enjoy my work very much.
You did a fair amount of work on the late, lamented 300-inch, Texas 300-inch.
Yes, I did.
I was the principal scientist, project scientist for that project.
How many years did that take off your life?
That was five years.
Five years.
Are you connected in any way with the SST, the Spectroscopic Survey Telescope?
I've been asked to and I've begun doing the work to design, to oversee the design and construction of the high resolution spectrograph for the SST.
I began that effort last fall with an international conference which I organized and which was held entirely by email.

has involved not only the international partners of the SST project, but a number of other observatories where I knew that there were high-resolution spectroscopists and people involved in the construction of high-resolution spectros.
Let me ask you a historical question.
If you held this conference entirely by email, were there any records kept of what went back
Everything was automatically recorded in real time.
I have all those records, both in my computer records and in hard copy.
I have not otherwise published the records.
I have simply made it known that those records are in my computer files and accessible to people locally and have let people know
by word of mouth that they are available.
Now, you're in an interesting position because you've done some work in planetary astronomy, but you're not really a planetary astronomer, so you have kind of an inside-outside view.
Yeah, that's right.
Do you think planetary astronomers are looked down upon by real astronomers?
Oh, to some extent, I know that's true.
Yes.
Well, of course, it's really hard to talk about how the 107-inch was viewed here in Texas, because it was a small department, so you really couldn't have big factions.
But when the idea of taking money from NASA to build a telescope that would spend a large amount of time working on other planets
Was that well received here by the staff and also by the administration of the university as far as you know?
Well, as far as I know, yes.
As you implied, the staff, the faculty was quite small at the time that we began the project.
There were some members of the faculty who did not participate actively and
so far as I'm aware, have never actually used the telescope since it was built.
And as far as I'm, that has been the only hint I have, I think, that there is anyone who felt that it was not a proper project to carry out.
I'm skipping around a bit here, but
Do you get requests from people to design things, or do you get an idea and say, hey, why don't we build this or design this or something, or is it a combination of both?
Not very many such requests from outside.
Of course, Harlan Smith is a great source of ideas.
would often ask, well, wouldn't it be a good idea to do this?
And I think more than most cases, more than half the cases, I would say no.
But there were certainly those cases where I said yes.
And Harlan Smith was always my strongest supporter in instrumentation.
deeply my interests in the reticon development and in the intensified reticon, which we called the self-scanned digicon.

He made the original suggestion concerning the construction of the octicon, which was, it doesn't exist anymore, but at the time that we built it, it was an array of eight linear reticon arrays butted end to end along the
photographic plate holder, effectively, of the 40 inch diameter, 1.8 meter focal length camera of the Kudai spectrograph.
That was completed in 1984.
We retired it.
Let me clarify a point.
It was built, and the NSF supported it, for the specific purpose to be an interim instrument until large format CCDs should become readily available.
And it served that purpose at the time that the Tektronix CCD 2048 by 2048 CCD
came close to being available, we retired it as we built the instrument that has now replaced it, which we call 2D Kudeng.
You mentioned that Harlan was always a strong supporter of yours, and obviously he's one guy I can't interview.
Tell me about Harlan.
Well, Harlan came here with strong support from the University of Chicago staff, in particular in 63, which was the couple of years after I came.
He came here already with ideas of expanding this department and building a much larger telescope, or at least a telescope equal to the 82-inch telescope.
He, it was his vision that eventually we would have a staff of something like 20 faculty members and a group of something like 50 graduate students.
At the time this sounded like an idle dream, but in fact it was not.
That is where we are now.
And it was indeed Harlan's drive that brought this about.
He did bring in the NASA funding for the 107-inch telescope in the mid-'60s, and we constructed that telescope and completed it in early 1969.
Basically, that was Harlan's telescope.
Didn't that come in over budget?
I left headquarters by then to go back.
I don't know any project that doesn't come in over budget to some extent.
To go back to your instrumentation life again, once you design something like a reticon or something and it's done and built, is there usually much interaction with the people that use it?
You know, coming back and saying, look Bob, you can turn it 90 degrees or something like this, or does it just go off into a black hole?
My instrument would be a total failure if it weren't for that type of interaction.
If an instrument, for example, is not used to begin with by the observing astronomers, then it might not as well have ever been built.
In my case, I've had very excellent relationships with observing astronomers.
We have worked together in developing the instruments.
We have worked together in developing the methods of using them.
And I think we kind of continue to see future development together.
Now to go back to Harlan again.
Do you think he might have done even more had he done a little less?
Would you mind rephrasing the question?
If he would have stopped and taken a breath once in a while.
There were times increasingly toward the end of his career when he met resistance to all that drive that he had.
The administration of the university was becoming
increasingly strapped for state funds over the past dozen years or so.
And Harlan Smith refused to allow that to slow him down.
Requests that he made

to the administration back in the early days, such as when the 170th was being built, were met, I think, much more eagerly than they were in later days when there simply wasn't that much of a margin between requests and the wherewithal to support them.
I'm not sure that he could have done any more than he did
whether he slowed down or speeded up in his drive.
As you're well aware, one of his dreams was astronomy from the surface of the moon.
And I don't know where that idea is going to go, and I don't know whether there would have been a better or worse chance for that ever to happen had he not passed away.
Well, let's start with your case.
But anyway, most astronomy departments are replete with backstabbing.
Did Harlan, I mean, and this place is actually fairly well known, justly or unjustly, for not really being that bad in that respect.
Did Harlan help with that or hinder or didn't make any difference?
because there were all these guys here.
One of Harlan's outstanding qualities was support of his people.
I have never heard him degrade any of the research or faculty people here.
He has supported people who, it's probably the opinion of most people around here, didn't deserve support.
Are we talking a group of all in this, too?
Well, yes, that's one.
I'm thinking specifically of the young man, Jack Hyde, who shot the
bullet holes in the 170-inch primary mirror back in, what was it, 69 or 70.
Harlan gave him a great deal of support afterwards.
That, I think, amazed everybody.
I understand that the man's wife also supported him greatly, and that eventually he was
worked himself into a much more comfortable position in life, but at the time things looked grim.
What piece of work, if you've turned out, do you think was your best?
You know, we're going to chisel something out of your tombstone.
Oh, I suppose it would be the Kudai spectrograph and the 107-inch telescope.
I have to qualify that to some extent in that that particular project, as true of a number of projects, wasn't the type of thing you do and then it's finished.
I designed the spectrograph, we got it built as part of the 107-inch construction project,
Well, my design of it was the optical design.
The mechanical design was done by with a lot of preliminary work here by our engineers.
So there were a lot of people involved in it.
But it got installed, and we started using it photographically.
And then we immediately built a scanner for it that very same year, which was in operation
within three months of the completion of the telescope.
It has been that way ever since.
It still is a project.
It is a continuing project.
And I've been involved with it, and nobody has told me to stop.
So I simply continue to allow it to grow and evolve.
try to keep up with the times.

There have been one difficulty with technology probably in general is that if you stop at a given time and adopt what's available at that time, it's very difficult to evolve away from that particular development in view of further, even better developments after that and one
tends to find oneself with obsolete equipment within a few years.
I've attempted to alleviate that as much as possible by trying to go on to the next step.
And one of those examples is the fact that we did build Opticon at a time when there wasn't a clear
direction toward getting very large array CCDs, and we gladly retired it when it was time to replace it with the next step up.
Are the detectors pretty much all CCDs now?
Yes, they're virtually all CCDs now.
The scanner, in fact, is still in place.
and is occasionally used for scanning, say, transmission profiles of interference filters, which makes it probably the best spectrograph in the world for that particular application.
It sure is.
So you have in the past taken N-ASA money.
Did you have any problems with them?
Or did they come through pretty well?
Or did they try and tell you what to do too much?
Well, I don't believe that I've ever directly requested a grant from NASA.
I have worked within the overall planetary grant of the McDonald Observatory.
and have made my requests through that grant.
I have been quite pleased with the support of NASA for my instrumentation project here.
Have you had any NSF support?
Yes.
And how does that compare?
My NSFs are, well, I've...
I mean, are they freer with their money or let you do more what you want?
There are times when I feel that NSF is freer with the money.
There are times when I feel that

that NASA, for whatever reason, perhaps it's individuals who happened to be in the office at that time, are rather more pessimistic about what I can do, or what anybody can do, particularly in ground-based astronomy, than the view that I get from NSF.
What do...
What do people, what is the reaction, the reactions of people that you meet when you tell them what you do for a living?
Do they think it's neat?
Do they think you're a parasite or what?
I haven't heard much reference to parasitism at all.
You're speaking, I presume, of people outside of strength.
Yeah, right.
I've always had the greatest respect from people with whom I've discussed these things.
Mike Belton got called that by a plumber, so I know it exists.
This again is personal opinion, but I'm building up personal opinions, a file of them.
Do you think astronomy has sold itself well, has done a good job of selling itself to the public?
I think it has, apparently so.

I suppose I could sound a little bit brash to say that I think we've done it very well here in Texas through our Stardate program, for example, our overall public outreach program, which I think is an exceptionally good one.
It has been very effective.
I can't give you numbers now, but every year we have more and more visitors at McDonald Observatory.
It's my understanding that some observatories restrict visitors quite a bit, and that had never been the philosophy of McDonald Observatory.
We have a visitor's center with a well-equipped staff.
associated directly with the visitors program which is also running the Stardate radio program and the Stardate magazine.
The public response to this has been extremely good.
I had occasion to visit the observatory
over the Easter weekend with my grandson's Boy Scout troop.
And we attended the public night at the observatory and the place was essentially packed with the public.
They are all there, eager and anxious to stand out there in the cold under the stars and have somebody point out constellations.
